column1: Genital sores may be painful or itchy, or may produce no symptoms.

Infections spread through sexual contact can cause these sores: - Herpes is a common cause painful sores - Genital warts may cause painless sores - Less common infections such as, Chancroid, Granuloma inguinale, Molluscum contagiosum, Syphilis Changes that may lead to cancer of the vulva (vulvar dysplasia) may appear as white, red, or brown patches on the vulva.
Skin cancers such as melanoma and basal cell and squamous cell carcinomas may also be found, but are less common.
A sitz bath may help relieve itching and crusting.

Call your health care provider if you: - Find any unexplained genital sore - Have a change in a genital sore - Have genital itching that does not go away with home care - Think you might have a sexually transmitted infection - Have pelvic pain, fever, vaginal bleeding, or other new symptoms as well genital sores
Your health care provider will perform a physical examination.
